ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a lot of knowledge about economic ideas that have influenced many aspects of our life today. The ideas spanned topics such as poverty reduction, sustainability, game theory, and finance, to name a few of the topics.
How to take notes effectively, basic knowledge of large economic ideas, and good insight to one economist that I wrote my paper on.
I didn't really learn a whole lot as I wasn't very engaged in the lectures.

I gained an understanding about the great ideas and economists that won nobel prizes in economics. It was nice to see the ideas we were studying in this class show up in other econ courses, and was great to already have an understanding. It also gave a better glimpse of what big contributions to economics look like and what areas seem interesting to me.
I learned about many Nobel Prize winning economists and their ideas. It helped me think about how economics was applicable to many aspects of life.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: One strength was the variety of ideas that were discussed. The weekly quizzes were also helpful because they ensured that we understood the content that he was teaching. Oftentimes, though, the class seemed a bit more like a small lecture than a seminar, and sometimes was not super interactive.

Strengths: light workload, interesting topic that is new each class, meet other first-years, easy to follow along 
Weaknesses: slightly boring to me, sometimes hard to understand my professor, I am not a huge fan of econonmics

The strengths are that it is an easy course with a low workload you can take for a social science credit. The weaknesses are that it can get boring quickly and you really don't need to pay attention or take any notes at all because the material covered in class is only sort of reviewed at the end of the week and isn't done so in much detail, and there are no midterms or finals or anything.

I liked that the course covers a wide range of topics in economics and highlights many important milestones (such as first woman, first black person) in the development of diversity in the field (which becomes clear is still quite low). The quizzes were a good way of testing our understanding of class material and the final paper a nice opportunity to explore an idea we were most interested in. I do wish we had a little more student-led discussions where possible; sometimes the ideas were not trivial and we needed some clarification first, but in some of them I think a student-led discussion might have worked (and an extra incentive to do the readings).
This class was very interesting and everything was explained well. There could have been more discussion between students.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, especially a student who wants to learn more about the many uses of economics.

Yes because you got to learn about cool people that impacted our world alongside other first-years. Easy class to add onto your schedule since there is not much work besides the paper that sneaks up on you at the end of the year.
I would only recommend if you're looking for an easy course to get a social science credit out of the way.

I would, both to econ students who want to get a better grasp of the historical development of the field and to non-econ students who want to get a glimpse of what economics is about beyond money and finance.
Yes this was one of the most thought provoking courses that I have taken. Every class taught something new.
